title: Quiz 4: Abnormal Puerperium & Sepsis
topicName: Unit Three Part Two : Abnormal Labour and Puerperium
description: Questions on puerperal infections, breast disorders, and thrombosis.

questions.question: Puerperal pyrexia is defined as a temperature of ___BLANK___ degrees Celsius or higher within 14-21 days postpartum.
questions.explanation: A temperature of 38°C indicates potential infection.

questions.question: Match the type of puerperal infection to its clinical presentation:

pairs.right: Persistent high fever (>39°C), rigors, rapid pulse

questions.explanation: Symptoms escalate from local pain to systemic toxicity (rigors, high fever).
questions.hint: Focus on the severity of symptoms.

questions.question: What is the primary difference between 'Breast Engorgement' and 'Mastitis'?

options.text: Engorgement is infection; Mastitis is congestion
Engorgement is bilateral congestion; Mastitis is usually unilateral infection
Mastitis occurs on day 3; Engorgement after week 2
Engorgement requires antibiotics; Mastitis does not

questions.explanation: Engorgement is physiological congestion (usually bilateral) around day 3. Mastitis is a bacterial infection (usually unilateral) occurring later.
questions.hint: One is physiological fluid buildup, the other is an infection.

questions.question: Which measures help prevent Cracked Nipples? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Correct attachment of the baby to the breast
Washing nipples with soap before every feed

questions.explanation: Correct positioning and hygiene prevent cracks. Soap can dry out nipples, causing cracks.

questions.question: Which of the following bacteria is an 'Exogenous' organism often causing puerperal sepsis?
questions.explanation: Staph aureus typically comes from outside sources (skin, dust, caregivers), whereas the others are often endogenous (from the patient's own bowel/tract).
questions.hint: Often associated with skin or respiratory carriers.

questions.question: A postpartum woman presents with a swollen, painful leg and a low-grade fever. What condition should you suspect?
questions.explanation: Unilateral leg swelling and pain are classic signs of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT), a risk in puerperium.

questions.question: Breastfeeding should ALWAYS be stopped immediately if a woman develops Mastitis.
questions.explanation: Breastfeeding often continues to drain the breast unless there is an abscess discharging pus. Emptying the breast is part of the treatment.
questions.hint: Stasis of milk makes the infection worse.

questions.question: Arrange the steps for managing a Breast Abscess:
questions.explanation: Diagnosis -> Decision on lactation -> Surgical drainage -> Post-op care -> Antibiotics.
questions.hint: You can't treat it until you know it's there.

questions.question: Identify the signs of 'Severe Puerperal Sepsis'. (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Severe sepsis involves systemic toxicity: high pulse, rigors, high fever, vomiting, and local uterine tenderness.
questions.hint: Think of signs indicating the whole body is fighting infection.

questions.question: What is the term for organisms that inhabit the patient's own body (e.g., bowel) and cause infection when transferred to the birth canal?
questions.explanation: Endogenous organisms originate from within the patient's own body.
